title: 105_hr1873
content: The "FERS Buyback Act of 1997" is also known as the FERS Buyback Act. It addresses the creditability of service for federal employees. The FERS Buyback Act of 1997 amends Section 8411(b) of title 5, United States Code to include service as a temporary or intermittent employee performed between December 31, 1988, and January 1, 1997, of at least 1 year's duration, if the individual later becomes subject to this chapter. The FERS Buyback Act of 1997 amends Section 8411 of title 5, United States Code to require employees or Members to deposit 1.3 percent of basic pay for service performed as a temporary or intermittent employee. Any deposit made more than 5 years later must include interest. The FERS Buyback Act of 1997 requires employees to deposit 1.3 percent of basic pay for temporary or intermittent service. If the deposit is not made within 5 years, the service is still creditable but annuity payments will be reduced. SEC. 3. PROVISIONS RELATING TO PERSONS WHO HAVE SEPARATED. The Office of Personnel Management will prescribe regulations for obtaining credit for service performed by individuals who have separated from Government service. Credit will only be given upon submission of a written application by December 31, 1999. Any annuity or survivor annuity will be recomputed to include the service described in the regulations. The Office of Personnel Management will prescribe regulations for obtaining credit for service performed by individuals who have separated from Government service. Credit will only be given upon submission of a written application by December 31, 1999. An annuity will be recomputed for amounts accruing more than 30 days after the application is submitted, with a reduction if the full deposit required is not timely made. Interest is not included in the deposit. SEC. 4. NOTIFICATION AND OTHER DUTIES OF THE OFFICE OF PERSONNEL MANAGEMENT. The Office of Personnel Management is required to inform individuals of their rights under the Act, assist in obtaining necessary information for service credits or annuity recomputations, and request information from relevant government entities regarding an individual's service history.
